National top stories

  • $40 per week to live in a shipping container: Inside horticulture's 'dark underbelly'

    Throughout the pandemic, farmers have become increasingly reliant on temporary migrants to fill labour shortages. But there are claims some workers are being routinely exploited — paid as little as $30 a day for back-breaking labour, while living in overcrowded, unsanitary accommodation.
  • analysis

    Is Moon Jae-in's visit more about geopolitics or commerce?

    Foreign policy experts are divided on whether the South Korean President's trip to Australia is a sign of "quiet alignment" with Australia and the US, or simply a move to secure Australian resources. 

  • Search for William Tyrrell's remains to end this week

    The "painstaking" four-week search for William Tyrrell's remains will end "in coming days", police say. The efforts were sparked by "new information", but have so far turned up nothing of note.

  • 'Moderate' La Niña's short stay won't threaten big wets of '11 and '74, says BOM

    The east coast is sodden, towns have gone under and summer has only just started. But it will take a lot to beat the  wettest summers. 

  • Contact tracing underway after three truck drivers who visited WA test positive for COVID

    The McGowan government publishes a list of exposure sites as three fully vaccinated truck drivers from South Australia test positive for COVID-19 after spending time in Western Australia.
  • live

    All of today's coronavirus news in the one spot

    Get up to speed with all of the coronavirus news from across Australia in our live COVID blog. Follow live.

  • Two Australian veterans receive prestigious US Silver Star award 50 years after being nominated

    Two Australian veterans are awarded the third-highest military combat decoration from the United States for their service to the US during the Vietnam War.

  • Former NRL player Brett Finch charged over alleged child abuse material offences

    The ex-Parramatta and Sydney Roosters player is on bail charged with five offences after being arrested in southern Sydney this morning.

  • Minister defends notorious Malmsbury centre amid fears laid out by former staff

    Victoria's Minister for Youth Justice, Natalie Hutchins, says she cannot guarantee an end to assaults on staff and young people at the troubled Malmsbury Youth Justice Centre.

  • Lockdowns favoured professionals and managers, while low-income casuals hit hardest

    With New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory in lockdown during August, new figures show nearly half the nation literally took their work home with them.

  • Basketball Australia called out for 'clear racial discrimination'

    An apologetic Basketball Australia has been caught out by an outdated rule that has been branded as "clear racial discrimination" by Melbourne Boomer Tiffany Mitchell.

  • Names, bank account details, pays, personal information of nearly 80,000 public sector workers accessed in cyber attack

    The South Australian Government is rushing to "address all potential areas of exposure" after confirming 80,000 public sector workers' details had been accessed by hackers.

  • Newcastle COVID outbreak could become one of 'highest-transmission events' in the world this year

    The Argyle House nightclub COVID-19 cluster has grown to 150, after 650 people checked into an event there last Wednesday.

  • US military accused of 'absolving itself of accountability' in Kabul strike as troops avoid discipline

    US troops will not be disciplined for launching a drone strike that killed 10 civilians, including seven children, in Kabul in August. 

  • Travelling 600km for a COVID test 'completely unviable', fed-up mum says

    Outback residents say it's absurd that COVID testing is not available anywhere near the SA-NT border, particularly amid a scare at the nearby APY Lands.

  • It's not Squid Game but 10 people are pitted against each other for cash … and they're teachers

    Footage of a "Dash for Cash" promotion, held during a hockey game in the US state of South Dakota, has prompted online outrage and sparked a national debate about school funding.

  • Experts attest to Madeley mum's mental impairment when she killed young daughters

    Both the defence and the prosecution in Perth mother Milka Djurasovic's trial agree she should not be found guilty of murdering her young girls Tiana and Mia, because she was not of sound mind at the time.

  • 'Cutting-edge' project to extract water from air in the outback. But is it safe?

    A small town in the Territory outback will play host to a new technology that sucks water from the atmosphere to create hydrogen – and the government is backing it with action. 

  • 'Like a turducken of bin fires': Best political cartoons of 2021 highlight the absurdities of the year that was

    In a year where statistical models and predictions were at the forefront of all Australians minds, the Behind the Lines exhibition has set out to showcase all the other — unexpected — things that 2021 had to offer.

  • Hours before she died, this mum was 'calm in the fact' her killer 'need not be a part' of her life

    Trefor Kingdon, 65, has pleaded guilty to stabbing his childhood sweetheart Mandy Melzer-Head to death at their remote rural home. On the night she died, the court heard, she texted him to say their relationship was over.

  • Australia Decides 2022: Who's in, who's out and how YOU could be in the running to represent Australia at Eurovision

    The field for next year's Australia Decides is taking shape, but what do we know about the performers in the running to be Australia's 2022 Eurovision entrants, and what two names will we have to wait for? Check out our guide to the event.

  • AdBlue 'price gouging' won't be solved easily, says haulage company

    A national milk haulage company says an extra two weeks' supply of AdBlue from Indonesia won't solve "price gouging" being experienced in Australia for the scarce diesel exhaust fluid.

  • Eddie Obeid's bid to get out of jail in time for Christmas

    Lawyers for Eddie Obeid and Ian Macdonald say the former NSW Labor ministers should be released on home detention ahead of an appeal against their conspiracy convictions. 

  • NT records one new COVID case in outbreak, three possible cases detected in remote communities

    The Northern Territory records one new case of COVID-19 related to the current outbreak, but authorities say three possible cases have been detected in remote communities.

  • Carl Williams' prison killer Matthew Johnson seeks to overturn murder conviction

    The man jailed for life in 2011 for killing underworld figure Carl Williams in a Victorian prison has filed an appeal against his murder conviction.

  • Two healthcare workers who visited aged care homes in Adelaide test positive to COVID-19

    Two healthcare workers who provided care at a number of residential aged care facilities in Adelaide test positive to COVID-19. Authorities are contacting impacted sites.

  • Donald Trump's former chief of staff held in criminal contempt of US Congress

    A US congressional committee investigating the January 6 attack on the Capitol votes unanimously to hold Donald Trump's former chief of staff Mark Meadows in criminal contempt of Congress.

  • These texts to Trump's former top aide during the Capitol riot show why his testimony could be key

    The name Mark Meadows may not ring a bell, but a US committee investigating January's attack on the Capitol believes his testimony could be key.

  • TGA issues warning about counterfeit ivermectin

    The national medical regulator warns people not to try and import ivermectin products, while also repeating warnings against using it to prevent or treat COVID-19.

As we inch closer to Christmas, two big threats are looming large across the globe: Inflation, and the Omicron variant. Both could have potentially catastrophic consequences for the economy and our wellbeing, writes David Taylor.

analysis

Australia's rivals have gained ground while our borders were closed

International students are heading to Canada, the UK and the US in record numbers despite the pandemic, but Australia and New Zealand continue to experience a dramatic drop in new international students, write Peter Hurley and Melinda Hildebrandt.
By Peter Hurley and Melinda Hildebrandt
analysis

It's legal to buy over-the-counter cannabis in Australia — but it’s still a long way from your local chemist

The sale of low-dose cannabidiol preparations over the counter at Australian pharmacies has been allowed since early this year. But you won't find any at your local chemist and there is a reason for that
By Jennifer Martin and Catherine Lucas
